Higher alcohols synthesis (HAS) is an important branch of syngas conversion, and Mo2C-based catalyst is a promising system for this reaction. However, the CO conversion and alcohols selectivity of current Mo2C-based catalysts are still low, which hinders their industrial application. Here, a series of Mo2C with three-dimensional hierarchically porous (3DHP) structures were prepared via a hard template method and their catalytic performance in HAS was investigated. The CO conversion and higher alcohols proportion of the optimal 3DHP catalyst were increased from 5.1 % and 60.4 % to 17.6 % and 70.5 %, respectively, compared with that of bulk Mo2C under similar total alcohols selectivity. The enhancement of the catalytic performance could be related to the increased number of active sites and the synergistic effect between multivalent Mo species. Additionally, the optimal 3DHP catalyst demonstrated good stability over a period of 200 h. This study provides a potential application for 3DHP materials and an alternative for designing efficient Mo2C catalysts for the HAS reactions. Graphical abstarct Image, graphical abstract Keywords Syngas Higher alcohols Mo2C Three-dimensional hierarchically porous structure Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction With fossil energy consumption and environmental pollution intensification, the realization of clean coal utilization has become a hot research topic [1,2]. As high-value chemicals, higher alcohols (typically referring to alcohols with carbon atoms of 2–6, named C2+ alcohols) could be used as fuels, fuel additives, and fine chemical raw materials [3–5]. Higher alcohols synthesis from coal via syngas (a mixture of CO and H2) is one of the most promising strategies [6,7]. Currently, there are four main types of HAS catalysts: rhodium-based catalysts, modified Fischer-Tropsch synthesis catalysts, modified methanol synthesis catalysts, and molybdenum-based catalysts [8–10]. Molybdenum-based catalysts are suitable for syngas with relatively higher sulfur content and lower H2/CO ratio due to their excellent sulfur resistance, significant water gas shift reaction (WGSR), and remarkable carbon deposition resistance [11–13]. Among the molybdenum-based catalysts studied, molybdenum sulfide-based catalysts possess the most excellent activity and higher alcohols selectivity [14]. Unfortunately, it is required to supplement sulfur (e.g., H2S) in the reaction feedstock because of the loss of sulfur from MoS2 during the catalytic reaction [15]. This makes it difficult to separate the S species from the HAS catalytic products, resulting in emissions in the form of SO2 or SO3 into the air and further environmental pollution [16]. Therefore, it is of practical significance to study and explore molybdenum carbide-based catalysts whose catalytic performance is second only to MoS2. Under typical HAS reaction conditions, the C2+ alcohols proportion of the alkali-modified molybdenum carbide catalysts system is higher [17], while the lower CO conversion and total alcohols selectivity urgently need to be solved. In the past two decades, researchers have conducted many studies on Mo2C concerning promoter modifications. The results suggest that Mo2C-based catalysts modified with various promoters, such as alkali metals [18–22], rare earth elements [23,24], noble metals [25,26], and transition metals [27–33], have various effects on catalytic performance. However, most of the research focuses on the Mo2C of bulk. The bulk Mo2C has the disadvantage of a smaller specific surface, lower porosity, and larger particle size, which makes fewer active sites on the catalyst surface exposed and leads to its lower intrinsic catalytic activity. Further optimizing such bulk Mo2C to boost its catalytic performance is crucial. Therefore, loading Mo2C on carriers has received wide attention because of its ability to form large specific surfaces to enhance catalytic efficiency [34]. Additionally, this method allows for adjusting the catalyst surface acidity to modify product selectivity [35]. However, carriers commonly chosen were metal oxides [34–37] and carbon materials [15,35,38,39], which will reduce the content of effective active components. As a result, it is reasonable and feasible to design Mo2C with a large specific surface area, small particle size, and high dispersion to improve the HAS catalytic activity while ensuring as much effective active component content as possible. Constructing molybdenum carbide with abundant pores represents one of the potential strategies to improve HAS catalytic performances. According to the literature [40,41], three-dimensional hierarchical porous architectures with larger surface areas are widely used in electrode design to enable faster and more efficient electron transfer, which is conducive to the sufficient utilization of space and the reduction of "dead space". In addition, similar study has been reported for HAS reaction. Yu and coworkers [42] demonstrated that higher alcohols could be generated with high selectivity from syngas over a three-dimensionally ordered macroporous Cu-Fe catalyst prepared by the colloidal crystal template method. Dai's group [43] also found on hierarchical KNiMo|ZnCrAl-based multifunctional catalysts that the hierarchical structure with higher specific surface area and appropriate pore diameter could improve the dispersion of the Mo precursor and generate the higher proportion of edge sites of MoS2 slabs, which enhances the ability of CO activation and CC coupling. Inspired by this, we prepared a series of three-dimensional hierarchically porous (3DHP) Mo2C nanoparticles with different pore volumes using the SiO2 hard template method. The pore-forming of the Mo2C increases its specific surface and pore volume, decreases its particle size, and adjusts its adsorption sites and valence state distribution, which significantly improved the catalytic performance of the 3DHP Mo2C. The results are valuable for the design of highly efficient Mo2C catalysts for HAS reaction. 2 Experimental sections 2.1 Materials Tetraethyl orthosilicate (C8H20O4Si, TEOS), ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O), potassium hydroxide (KOH), and potassium carbonate (K2CO3) were purchased from Aladdin Biochemical Techemical Technology Co., Ltd. Dicyandiamide (C2H4N4) was purchased from Alfa Aesar. Nano silica dioxide (∼ 50 ± 5 nm) was purchased from Brofos nanotechnology Co., Ltd. 25–28 wt % ammonia (NH3·H2O), and ethanol (EtOH, 99.8 %) were purchased from Innochem Technology Co., Ltd. All the reagents were analytical grade and used without further purification. All solutions were prepared using deionized (DI) water. 2.2 Experimental method 2.2.1 Synthesis of x-SiO2 spheres According to the previous literature [44], SiO2 spheres with different particle sizes were synthesized. In a typical synthesis, 30.0 mL EtOH, 10.0 mL H2O, 0.6 mL NH3·H2O, and 2 mL (or 2.5 mL) TEOS were transferred to the flask respectively and stirred at ambient temperature for 12 h. Then the obtained solids were washed with H2O and EtOH to neutral. The resulting samples were confirmed as 100 nm and 200 nm SiO2 spheres. In addition, the 50 nm SiO2 sphere purchased was used directly without purification. All powders were recorded as x-SiO2 (x = 50, 100, 200), where x represented the particle sizes of the SiO2 sphere template. 2.2.2 Synthesis of 3DHP Mo2C First, the ammonium heptamolybdate tetrahydrate, dicyandiamide, and the template of x-SiO2 (x = 50, 100, 200) were mixed at a mass ratio of 1:1:2 in deionized water. The mixtures were stirred with ultrasonic for 30 min, dried, and named as x-SiO2/Mo2C precursors. Then, x-SiO2/Mo2C precursors were thermally treated from room temperature to 750 °C with 5 °C/min under 10 % H2/Ar atmosphere and held at 750 °C for 6 h. The obtained solids are called x-SiO2/Mo2C. Finally, the x-SiO2/Mo2C were stirred in a 2 M KOH solution at 50 °C for 12 h to remove the x-SiO2 template completely. The obtained black solids were 3DHP Mo2C, denoted as x-p-Mo2C (x = 50, 100, 200, p represents porous). For comparison, the bulk Mo2C was used as a reference catalyst and labeled as b-Mo2C. The preparation steps of b-Mo2C were the same as x-p-Mo2C, except without the SiO2 sphere template. 2.2.3 Preparation of catalysts Prior to evaluating the catalytic performance, the K2CO3 promoter at K/Mo molar ratio of 1.0 was added to x-p-Mo2C or b-Mo2C. Taking 100-p-Mo2C as an example, 0.6500 g K2CO3 and 0.9594 g 100-p-Mo2C were mixed and ground in EtOH until dried so K2CO3 was evenly dispersed on 100-p-Mo2C. 2.3 Characterizations Micro-morphological images of the samples were collected by a Hitachi S-4800 field-emission scanning electron microscope (SEM) and an FEI Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscope (TEM). X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained by a PANalytical X'pert PRO X-ray powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation at 40 kV and 40 mA. N2 adsorption-desorption tests were performed by the Micromeritics ASAP 2460 physical adsorption instrument. Specific surface area and pore size distribution of the samples were calculated by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) methods, respectively. CO temperature programmed desorption (CO-TPD) experiments were carried out on a Builder PCA-1200 chemisorption instrument to analyze CO adsorption by the samples. Before the test, all samples required to be impregnated with K2CO3 (K/Mo molar ratio of 1) and then pretreated under a stream of syngas (VH2/VCO=1) for 20 h at 300 °C. Next, 0.100 g sample was purged under Ar flow at 100 °C for 30 min and cooled down to 50 °C. Subsequently, the sample was saturated with 5 % CO/Ar at 50 °C for one hour, followed through Ar flow for one hour to eliminate physically adsorbed CO molecules. Finally, the samples were heated from ambient temperature to 900 °C under argon at 10 °C/min, while the desorbed gas was identified by mass spectrometry, and the ion signals at m/z = 28 were recorded. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) tests were performed on a Thermo Fisher ESCALAB 250Xi photoelectron spectrometer with a 1486.6 eV Kα aluminum X-ray source. What needs to be noticed is that all samples used for characterization were after HAS reaction at 300 °C and were etched for 5 nm by Ar+ before testing to avoid as much oxidation interference on the catalyst surface as possible. The binding energy position, peak area, and FWHM of the Mo 3d orbitals were analyzed and fitted according to the previous literature [45,46]. Besides, all binding energies were calibrated using the C 1 s at 284.8 eV. 2.4 Catalytic evaluation test The catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts for higher alcohols synthesis was evaluated on a fixed-bed stainless steel reactor with an inner diameter of 8 mm. For each experiment, 0.4 g of catalyst (40–60 mesh) was diluted to 5 mL by quartz sand with the same particle size and filled in the constant temperature zone of the reactor. The catalytic performance evaluation was carried out under the conditions of T = 300 °C, P = 8.0 MPa, GHSV (gas hourly space velocity) =3000 mL·gcat. −1·h−1, and V(H2)/V(CO)/V(N2) = 47.5/47.5/5.0, where the N2 was used as the internal standard. All catalysts were activated under syngas for 12 h at 300 °C. After the catalysts were stabilized, the products and feed gas were detected by gas chromatography online. The data were collected every 4 h for a total of 3 times under the same reaction conditions to avoid experimental errors. The CO conversion (XCO) and product selectivity (Si) are calculated by Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. Anderson-Schulz-Flory (ASF) plots are calculated by Eq. (3). C i assigns the C moles of the i product. n is the number of carbon atoms in a product. w n is the weight fraction of the product with carbon number n. α means the chain growth factor. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Preparation and characterization of 3DHP Mo2C and b-Mo2C The 3DHP Mo2C were synthesized via a hard template method, and the scheme of the synthesizing processes is shown in Fig. 1 . Typically, the hard template x-SiO2 spheres are fully dispersed in a solution of ammonium heptamolybdate and dicyandiamide to obtain x-SiO2/Mo2C precursor. Then, the obtained precursor was subjected to carbothermal reduction. Finally, the acquired mixture (x-SiO2/Mo2C) was etched in KOH solution to eliminate the template x-SiO2, which is different from the previous HF etching reported in the literature [47]. This is because more acidic sites facilitate alcohol dehydration reaction and inhibit HAS, but more basic sites favor alcohol synthesis [48,49]. Therefore, in order to favor more basic sites on the sample surface, KOH solution is chosen instead of HF solution when etching the template x-SiO2. In addition, to clarify the properties of the 3DHP structure, b-Mo2C was also prepared using the same method except without x-SiO2 spheres. The microscopic morphologies of the x-SiO2 template and x-p-Mo2C were investigated by electron microscopy technology. Fig. S1 shows that the x-SiO2 presents uniform and dispersed spheres with particle sizes of 50, 100, and 200 nm, respectively. The morphology images of x-p-Mo2C prepared using x-SiO2 as the template are shown in Fig. 2 . In Fig. 2 (a, d, g), different sizes of hemispherical holes were observed on the x-p-Mo2C surface, and the diameters of these holes are consistent with those of x-SiO2 spheres. Moreover, the TEM pictures in Fig. 2 (b, e, h) show the existence of tunnels interconnected by porosity in the interior of x-p-Mo2C, confirming that x-p-Mo2C samples have a three-dimensional porous structure. Besides, the b-Mo2C in Fig. 2 (j, k) shows a solid blocky structure with an average diameter of 0.8 μm. Further magnification of the HRTEM images in Fig. 2 (c, f, i, l) reveals that the lattice fringes of x-p-Mo2C and b-Mo2C correspond to β-Mo2C. Fig. 3 shows the phase structure of the sample, which was obtained by XRD. The diffraction peaks of the x-p-Mo2C and b-Mo2C were observed at 34.3°, 37.9°, 39.4°, 52.1°, 61.5°, 69.5°, 74.6°, and 75.5°, respectively, which can be indexed to the β-Mo2C standard card (JCPDS #35–0787). However, the x-p-Mo2C shows broader diffraction peaks than the b-Mo2C, indicating the poorer crystallinity and smaller crystal grains of the former. The crystallite sizes of Mo2C in x-p-Mo2C and b-Mo2C calculated according to Scherer's formula are displayed in Table 1 . The crystallite sizes of Mo2C gradually increased from 7.9 nm to 22.0 nm as the template size increased from 50 nm to 200 nm. In comparison, b-Mo2C showed a maximum crystallite size of 25.9 nm. The texture properties of Mo2C after porous treatment have been transformed compared with that of the b-Mo2C, as shown in Fig. 4 a. The N2 adsorption-desorption curves and the hysteresis loop types of x-p-Mo2C and b-Mo2C were assigned to type IV isotherm and type H3 loop, respectively, indicating that the crack holes were produced [50]. With the template size increased from 50 nm to 200 nm, the specific surface area of x-p-Mo2C gradually decreased from 97.9 m2/g to 40.9 m2/g (Table 1), but it is still far larger than that of b-Mo2C (4.8 m2/g). In terms of pore size distribution, b-Mo2C has a relatively broad pore size range spanning from micropores to macropores (Fig. 4b), whereas the pore size range of x-p-Mo2C is relatively narrow. Especially when the template size was 50 nm and 100 nm, the pore size converged on 3.0 nm and 14.9–18.1 nm, forming the hierarchically porous structure. Besides, it is clear from the pore volume (Table 1) that x-p-Mo2C has a 7.5–10 times improvement over that of b-Mo2C. Compared with the bulk structure, the interconnected pore structure could facilitate the catalyst exposing more active sites and contacting with more catalytic feedstocks, which promotes the catalytic performance. 3.2 Catalytic performance in HAS In this study, alkali metal promoter K2CO3 was selected to modify all catalysts prior to the HAS performance evaluation. In general, an additional alkali metal promoter was added to neutralize the surface acidity of the catalysts, which is the aim for increasing the active sites of non-dissociative CO adsorption [51,52]. The HAS catalytic performance of 3DHP structured Mo2C was investigated under the 300 °C, 8.0 MPa, 3000 mL·gcat −1·h−1, V(H2)/V(CO) =1 and compared with those of b-Mo2C. The catalytic results of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 5 . It can be observed in Fig. 5a that with the template size increased from 50 nm to 200 nm, the CO conversion gradually decreased from 22.3 % to 13.4 % (line chart), while the total alcohols selectivity (SROH) remained basically unchanged (about 37 %). Fig. 5b reveals that the C2+ alcohols proportion in the total alcohols exhibited an increasing trend followed by decreasing with increasing template size. Generally, most of the catalysts exhibit a seesaw-like trend between CO conversion and alcohols selectivity, i.e., the alcohols selectivity decreases with the CO conversion increasing and vice versa. Evidently, the catalytic performance of 3DHP Mo2C exhibits an exceptional tendency, which is a favorable phenomenon for the HAS reaction. As a result, the CO conversion and C2+ alcohols STY of the 100-p-Mo2C catalyst were both ∼ 3.5 times higher than those of the b-Mo2C catalyst. Meanwhile, the maximum of the C2+ alcohols proportion also occurs on the 100-p-Mo2C catalyst and reaches 70.5 %. Although the b-Mo2C has basically similar total alcohols selectivity, the CO conversion and the C2+ alcohols proportion in alcohols are only 5.1 % and 60.4 %. Therefore, considering both CO conversion and C2+ alcohols proportion, the optimal catalyst should be 100-p-Mo2C. The CO conversion, total alcohols selectivity, C2+ alcohols proportion in alcohols, and STY of C2+ alcohols for the optimal catalyst are 17.6 %, 36.7 %, 70.5 %, and 101.8 mL·gcat −1·h−1, respectively. As shown in Table 2 , the HAS catalytic performance of 100-p-Mo2C in this study was compared with that of the Mo2C catalysts reported in the literature under similar reaction conditions. The articles that did not provide information on CO2 selectivity were excluded because they could not enable a direct comparison. By comprehensively considering the catalytic reaction conditions, CO conversion, total alcohols selectivity and C2+ alcohols proportion in alcohols, it was found that the catalytic performance of the 100-p-Mo2C catalyst was superior to that reported in the literature. Besides, the quasi-ASF distribution of the product alcohols and hydrocarbons was calculated, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 . In the product of alcohols and hydrocarbons, the logarithm of the product mass fraction (Ln(Wn %/n)) and the carbon number (n) exhibit a linear relationship. The chain growth probabilities of alcohols and hydrocarbon were calculated from the slope of the quasi-ASF plot [54,55]. In Fig. 6a-c, with the size of template increases, the chain growth factors of alcohols (αROH) and hydrocarbons (αRHx) exhibit a volcanic trend shape. Under the template size of 100 nm, the 100-p-Mo2C catalyst obtains the maximum αROH and αRHx, which are 0.34 and 0.31, respectively. Compared the chain growth probability of alcohols (0.30) and hydrocarbon (0.29) of b-Mo2C catalyst, that of 100-p-Mo2C catalyst is still improved (Fig. 6d). 3.3 Structure-activity relationship The structure-activity relationship of 3DHP Mo2C catalysts was further analyzed and investigated. First, it is obvious in Fig. 7 that the CO conversion of the catalysts shows a similar changing trend with its texture properties, i.e., the CO conversion decreases gradually with the decrease of specific surface area and porosity of 3DHP Mo2C. The larger the specific surface area and pore volume of the catalyst, the more exposed active sites, and the higher the catalytic activity. Thus, the 3DHP Mo2C exhibits a significant enhancement in CO conversion compared with b-Mo2C. For 3DHP Mo2C catalysts, in addition to the increase of the CO conversion, the proportion of C2+ alcohols was also enhanced under the similar selectivity of total alcohols (Fig. 5b). According to the literature, the synthesis of higher alcohols follows the CO insertion and dual-active sites cooperation mechanism [56–59]. Specifically, it includes the following steps: (1) CO dissociation and CC coupling occur on the catalyst surface to form alkyl species CxHy*; (2) CO non-dissociative adsorption form CO* species, which insert into CxHy* to obtain CxHyCO*; (3) Finally, CxHyCO* is further hydrogenated to generate higher alcohols. The optimal synergistic cooperation of the dual-active sites, for example, a suitable ratio of CO dissociative adsorption sites and CO non-dissociative adsorption sites is required in these steps to obtain the highest C2+ alcohols proportion. Therefore, the enhancement of the C2+ alcohols proportion in 3DHP Mo2C catalyst could be related to a change of the ratio of CO dual-active sites on the catalyst after the porous treatment. Therefore, the CO adsorption behavior on the catalysts over different active sites was explored by CO-TPD-MS. The desorption profiles on x-p-Mo2C and b-Mo2C catalysts are presented in Fig. 8 , and each fitted and integrated spectrum was shown in Fig. S2. Detailed integrated area results are displayed in Table 3 . Three types of CO desorption peaks were detected for all catalysts: low-temperature desorption peaks below 200 °C, medium-temperature desorption peaks at 200–500 °C, and high-temperature desorption peaks over 500 °C. These three types of desorption peaks are basically in agreement with the CO adsorption kinds of Mo-based catalysts reported in the literature [52,60-62]. For simplicity, these three types of desorption peaks are referred as peak α, peak β, and peak γ, respectively. Generally, peak α species are assigned to CO physisorption and cannot activate CO, which has no effect on the catalytic performance [61]. Subsequently, the peaks β and γ are corresponding to non-dissociative and dissociative adsorption of CO, respectively, which will be mainly analyzed. Obviously, the x-p-Mo2C catalysts exhibit significantly enhanced CO chemisorption capacity (the integral area of β+γ) than the b-Mo2C catalyst, and the CO chemisorption capacity also decreased with the increase of the template size. These results were well consistent with the results of CO conversion. Additionally, the ratios of non-dissociative adsorption and dissociative adsorption peak area of the samples were also analyzed. It was found that b-Mo2C shows the highest β/γ value, indicating that the surface of b-Mo2C possessed more non-dissociative adsorption sites to promote the generation of CO* species while the CO dissociation and CC coupling are not sufficient, which could increase the formation of methanol product. Therefore, the b-Mo2C exhibits the highest methanol proportion (Fig. 5b). The decrease of β/γ value on x-p-Mo2C indicates that the ratio of CO adsorption sites of the samples was changed following the porous treatment. According to the reported mechanism, promoting the synthesis of C2+ alcohols requires a balance of CO* insertion and CC coupling. Thus, the optimal C2+ alcohols proportion is achieved when a moderate β/γ value is available on the 100-p-Mo2C catalyst. To further explore the influence of the surface species of the catalysts on alcohols proportion, the XPS tests on the spent x-p-Mo2C and b-Mo2C catalysts were performed. The fitted Mo 3d spectra of the samples are shown in Fig. 9 , and the percentages of the corresponding valence states are listed in Table S1. Previous research revealed a dual-active site on the surface of the Mo2C-based catalyst, namely low valence states species (Mo0–2+) and high valence states species (Mo4–5+) [46, 56]. The Mo0–2+ species are the active centers that stimulate CO dissociation and carbon chain growth to form the alkyl substance CxHy*. While the Mo4–5+ species are active centers for CHO* insertion via non-dissociative adsorption of CO. Thus, the (Mo4++Mo5+)/Mo2+ content on the catalyst surface is closely related to the C2+ alcohols proportion. The higher (Mo4++Mo5+)/Mo2+ content, the more CO non-dissociative adsorption sites proportion and the less CO dissociative adsorption sites proportion on the catalyst surface. Under this condition, the generation of alcohol products was favorable, but the ability to promote chain growth diminished meanwhile. In other words, two types of adsorption sites must synergize in a moderate proportion to obtain the best proportion of C2+ alcohols. As shown in Table 4 , b-Mo2C shows the highest (Mo4++Mo5+)/Mo2+ ratio, which is consistent with the result that it has the highest methanol proportion (Fig. 5b). However, although the (Mo4++Mo5+)/Mo2+ ratio on the 100-p-Mo2C surface is lower, two types of adsorption sites of CO* insertion and CC coupling sites reach a moderate balance at this point, so the optimal C2+ alcohols proportion is achieved. It is obvious that the changing trend of the active sites ratio (Mo4++Mo5+)/Mo2+ is consistent with the CO-TPD-MS results (Table 3), further explaining the reason for the high C2+ alcohols proportion in 100-p-Mo2C catalyst. 3.4 Catalyst stability The stability of the 100-p-Mo2C catalyst was evaluated over 200 h under 300 °C, 8.0 Mpa, 3000 mL·gcat. −1·h − 1, and V(H2)/V(CO) = 1, and the results are exhibited in Fig. 10 . The figure reveals that the CO conversion remained basically stable during 200 h reaction. Both alcohols and hydrocarbon selectivity stabilized at ∼ 52 % and ∼ 48 %, respectively, after an induction period of 20 h. The distribution of higher alcohols in the alcohols was stabilized at ∼ 67 % (Fig. 10b). The above results demonstrated that the 100-p-Mo2C catalyst maintained good stability over 200 h. 4 Conclusions In this study, a series of Mo2C with three-dimensional hierarchically porous structures were prepared via a hard template method and their catalytic performance in HAS was investigated. On the one hand, the 3DHP structure could increase the specific surface area, improve the porosity, and reduce the particle size, which are beneficial for a catalyst to expose more active sites and improve the CO conversion. On the other hand, the 3DHP structure could effectively alter the valence distribution and thus the CO adsorption sites on the catalysts surface. This could promote the synergistic coordination of dissociative and non-dissociative adsorption sites and facilitate the formation of higher alcohols. Compared with that of bulk Mo2C, the CO conversion and C2+ alcohols proportion of the optimal 100-p-Mo2C increased from 5.1 % and 60.4 % to 17.6 % and 70.5 %, respectively, under the premise that the total alcohols selectivity was basically similar. This catalytic performance exceeded that of similar catalysts reported in the literature. Moreover, the optimal 100-p-Mo2C catalyst exhibited good stability over 200 h. This study provides a potential application for 3DHP materials and an alternative for designing efficient Mo2C-based catalysts for HAS reactions. coredata.dc:description: Higher alcohols synthesis (HAS) is an important branch of syngas conversion, and Mo2C-based catalyst is a promising system for this reaction. However, the CO conversion and alcohols selectivity of current Mo2C-based catalysts are still low, which hinders their industrial application. Here, a series of Mo2C with three-dimensional hierarchically porous (3DHP) structures were prepared via a hard template method and their catalytic performance in HAS was investigated. The CO conversion and higher alcohols proportion of the optimal 3DHP catalyst were increased from 5.1 % and 60.4 % to 17.6 % and 70.5 %, respectively, compared with that of bulk Mo2C under similar total alcohols selectivity. The enhancement of the catalytic performance could be related to the increased number of active sites and the synergistic effect between multivalent Mo species. Additionally, the optimal 3DHP catalyst demonstrated good stability over a period of 200 h. This study provides a potential application for 3DHP materials and an alternative for designing efficient Mo2C catalysts for the HAS reactions.
coredata.dc:title: Remarkably enhanced catalytic performance of three-dimensional hierarchically porous Mo2C catalysts for higher alcohols synthesis from syngas
